questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serotonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex .
  • ➤ Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? ( NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.
  • • Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:
  • • Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials. Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.
  • • Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  • • Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  • • Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  • • Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.
  • • Option A. No change:
  • • Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.
  • • Option B. Becomes more negative:
  • • Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.
  • • Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.correct_answer: D. Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is determined by the balance of pressures acting on the glomerulus. The key pressures involved are the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which drives filtration, and the oncotic pressure, which opposes it. Additionally, the hydrostatic pressure within Bowman's capsule also opposes filtration.
  • • Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure : This is the back pressure exerted by the fluid already in Bowman's capsule. If this pressure increases, it opposes the hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries, leading to a decrease in GFR. For example, conditions such as ureteric obstruction can increase this pressure, resulting in reduced GFR.
  • • Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure : This pressure pushes fluid out of the capillaries and into Bowman's capsule, thus increasing GFR. Therefore, increasing this pressure would not decrease GFR.
  • • Option A. Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • • Option B. Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure : Oncotic pressure is the "holding" pressure due to plasma proteins. A decrease in this pressure would result in less opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR, not decreasing it.
  • • Option B. Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
  • • Option C. Increase in renal plasma flow : An increase in renal plasma flow generally leads to an increase in GFR because more plasma is being filtered through the kidneys.
  • • Option C. Increase in renal plasma flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure decreases GFR

questions.text: Cellular junctions present in a cardiac muscle are all except? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Zonula occludens are absent in cardiac muscle; instead, this muscle type prominently features fascia adherens, gap junctions, and macula adherens, which are essential for mechanical stability and coordinated contraction.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigeminal Nerve (V) is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing).
  • ➤ Trigeminal Nerve (V)
  • ➤ It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).
  • ➤ The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets.
  • ➤ Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

questions.text: At what intervals do migratory motor complexes (MMCs) reoccur in the gastrointestinal tract? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Migratory motor complexes are cyclical, recurring motor activities that occur during the fasting state to facilitate the clearance of undigested particles and secretions from the stomach through to the small intestine. They appear every 90 minutes. These complexes are driven by motilin, a hormone whose levels peak periodically, promoting these rhythmic contractions that sweep through the gut. This mechanism prevents bacterial overgrowth and ensures that the digestive tract is ready for the next meal.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option a (60 minutes) is incorrect as it does not align with the typical 90-minute cycle of MMCs. Option c (120 minutes) and option d (150 minutes) are incorrect as they exceed the normal frequency of MMCs, which generally occur every 90 minutes.
  • • Option a (60 minutes) is incorrect as it does not align with the typical 90-minute cycle of MMCs.
  • • Option c (120 minutes) and option d (150 minutes) are incorrect as they exceed the normal frequency of MMCs, which generally occur every 90 minutes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Migratory motor complexes reappear every 90 minutes in the gut, primarily driven by peaks in motilin levels during the fasting state, facilitating the clearance of the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Burst forming units

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Erythropoietin (EPO) primarily acts on early erythroid progenitor cells, particularly the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E). The BFU-E is among the earliest erythroid progenitor cells and requires EPO to proliferate and differentiate into more mature forms of red blood cell precursors.
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E). CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells. Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.
  • • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E).
  • • BFU-E:
  • • CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells.
  • • CFU-E:
  • • Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.
  • • Role of EPO:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Colony forming units: This is a later stage than BFU-E and is also influenced by EPO but not the earliest.
  • • Option B. Colony forming units:
  • • Option C. Late erythroblast stage: EPO's influence diminishes as cells mature to this stage.
  • • Option C. Late erythroblast stage:
  • • Option D. Normoblast stage: This is a more mature stage of erythroid development where EPO has minimal effect.
  • • Option D. Normoblast stage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythropoietin is most effective at the burst forming unit stage of red blood cell development, where it stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of these early progenitor cells into more mature red blood cells.

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function. The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads. LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells : Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.
  • • Option B. Sertoli cells
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules : Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.
  • • Option C. Seminiferous tubules
  • • Option D. Epididymis : Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.
  • • Option D. Epididymis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

questions.text: Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: ( INICET Nov 2022) Oxygen: Simple diffusion Glucose: Facilitated diffusion Sodium: Voltage-gated channel Sodium: Secondary active transport Calcium: Active transport
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All of the mentioned substances and their associated transport mechanisms are correct: Oxygen via simple diffusion, glucose via facilitated diffusion, sodium via voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport, and calcium via active transport.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of frequent urination, nocturia, and recent episodes of bedwetting. She reports drinking large amounts of water due to constant thirst. A 24-hour urine collection reveals a total volume of 7 liters with an osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. Blood tests show serum sodium at 148 mEq/L. ADH assay reveals a level of 0.8 pg/mL, and MRI of the brain reveals the absence of the normal bright spot on T1-weighted images. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's clinical presentation, including excessive urination, nocturia, and low urine osmolarity, along with a low ADH level and absence of the posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI, strongly indicate Central Diabetes Insipidus (CDI). In CDI, the deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) production or release from the posterior pituitary leads to inadequate water reabsorption in the kidneys, resulting in high urine output and low osmolarity. The low ADH levels and MRI findings confirm the diagnosis, distinguishing it from other forms of polyuria such as nephrogenic DI, where ADH is produced but not effective.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) HHS typically occurs in patients with poorly controlled diabetes and presents with severe hyperglycemia, dehydration, and altered mental status. Although it can cause polyuria, it would not result in low ADH levels or the absence of the posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI, making this diagnosis less likely in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • A. Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS)
  • • Option B. Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus Nephrogenic DI results from kidney resistance to ADH, not from a deficiency in ADH production. ADH levels would be elevated or normal, and there would be no absence of the posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI, which helps differentiate it from central DI.
  • • Option
  • • B. Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus
  • • Option D. Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) SIADH is characterized by excessive ADH secretion, leading to water retention, low serum sodium, and concentrated urine. It would present with low urine output, high urine osmolarity, and hyponatremia, which is the opposite of this patient’s presentation, making SIADH an incorrect diagnosis.
  • • Option
  • • D. Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central Diabetes Insipidus (CDI) is caused by a deficiency in ADH production or release, leading to high urine output, low urine osmolarity, and normal to low ADH levels. Diagnostic confirmation includes water deprivation tests, desmopressin response, and MRI findings such as absence of the posterior pituitary bright spot, differentiating it from nephrogenic DI and conditions like HHS.
  • ➤ MMS algorithm for finding out the cause :
  • ➤ MMS algorithm for finding out the cause

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dead space volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The single breath nitrogen method (Fowler's method) is used to measure the anatomical dead space volume, which is the volume of air in the respiratory passages where no gas exchange occurs. This method provides a precise measurement of dead space by analyzing the nitrogen concentration in expired air following a single breath of pure oxygen.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.
  • ➤ Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:
  • ➤ Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:
  • ➤ Where:
  • ➤ Where:
  • ➤ R is the resistance is pie symbol r is radius is viscosity L is length
  • ➤ R is the resistance
  • ➤ is pie symbol
  • ➤ r is radius
  • ➤ is viscosity
  • ➤ L is length
  • ➤ According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.
  • ➤ Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rectal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For accurate measurement of core body temperature in cases of suspected hypothermia, rectal temperature is the preferred method, especially in extreme environmental conditions like those in Siachen.

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Factor 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.
  • • Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.
  • • This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Factor 11 : Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.
  • • Option B. Factor 11
  • • Option C. Tissue factor : Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.
  • • Option C. Tissue factor
  • • Option D. Factor 5 : Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.
  • • Option D. Factor 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: D. Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment

options.label: C
options.text: IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.correct_answer: C. IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: In a clinical study on lung function, which condition does not result in decreased diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO)? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) measures how well gases can pass from the air sacs of the lungs into the blood. It is usually decreased in conditions where the alveolar walls are thickened or destroyed, or the blood flow around the alveoli is impaired. In conditions like interstitial lung disease, emphysema, and pulmonary vascular disease, the DLCO is typically reduced due to damage to the lung tissue or blood vessels, reducing gas exchange efficiency.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Interstitial lung disease : Increases the thickness of the alveolar walls, reducing DLCO. Option C. Emphysema : Destroys alveolar walls, reducing the surface area for gas exchange and thereby decreasing DLCO. Option D. Pulmonary vascular disease : Reduces the blood flow to the lungs' gas exchange areas, lowering DLCO.
  • • Option B. Interstitial lung disease : Increases the thickness of the alveolar walls, reducing DLCO.
  • • Option B. Interstitial lung disease
  • • Option C. Emphysema : Destroys alveolar walls, reducing the surface area for gas exchange and thereby decreasing DLCO.
  • • Option C. Emphysema
  • • Option D. Pulmonary vascular disease : Reduces the blood flow to the lungs' gas exchange areas, lowering DLCO.
  • • Option D. Pulmonary vascular disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polycythemia, unlike other listed conditions, actually leads to an increased DLCO due to the higher red blood cell count, which improves oxygen-carrying capacity and enhances gas exchange.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Battle sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A primigravida came with 6 cm cervical dilatation and a contraction rate of 3/10 minutes. Which stage of labor is she in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1st stage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is in the 1st stage of labor, which is defined as the onset of true labor pain until the full dilation of the cervix. The 1st stage of labor can be further classified as:
  • • Latent phase: Cervical dilation of less than 5 cm. Active phase: Cervical dilation of 5 cm or more.
  • • Latent phase: Cervical dilation of less than 5 cm.
  • • Latent phase:
  • • Active phase: Cervical dilation of 5 cm or more.
  • • Active phase:
  • • Earlier, this cutoff for the active phase was considered at 4 cm.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. 2nd stage: The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilation and ends with the delivery of the fetus. Since the cervix is not fully dilated (10 cm), the patient is not in the second stage.
  • • Option B. 2nd stage:
  • • Option C. 3rd stage: The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the fetus has not yet been delivered.
  • • Option C. 3rd stage:
  • • Option D. 4th stage: The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the delivery process is still ongoing.
  • • Option D. 4th stage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 1st stage of labor, which involves cervical dilation from the onset of true labor pain until full dilation, is divided into latent and active phases, with the active phase beginning at 5 cm dilation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: Mark the option which develops from the structure marked A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with crushing chest pain that started 3 hours ago while he was watching television. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with nausea and diaphoresis. His vital signs are: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 95 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. Physical examination reveals no jugular venous distension, clear lungs, and a normal S1 and S2 without murmurs. An ECG shows ST depression and T wave inversion in the anterior chest leads. Troponin levels are elevated. What is the best initial management approach for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient's clinical presentation, ECG findings of ST depression and T wave inversion, and elevated troponin levels indicate Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI). NSTEMI is typically caused by a subtotal occlusion of a coronary artery with a platelet-rich thrombus leading to ischemia. The initial management includes dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) such as aspirin and anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). These treatments help prevent further thrombus formation and reduce the risk of distal embolization. After stabilization, the patient should undergo coronary angiography (CAG) to assess the extent of coronary artery disease and guide further management, such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Immediate fibrinolysis Fibrinolysis is reserved for ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) with complete coronary occlusion. In NSTEMI, where the thrombus is usually platelet-rich and partial, fibrinolysis is ineffective and increases the risk of bleeding without providing benefit.
  • • Option
  • • A. Immediate fibrinolysis
  • • Option C. Emergent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) CABG is considered for severe multivessel disease or left main coronary artery involvement, often after failed PCI or in cases with specific anatomical considerations. It is not the immediate treatment for NSTEMI without prior evaluation with coronary angiography.
  • • Option
  • • C. Emergent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)
  • • Option D. Observation with serial ECG monitoring Observation alone is insufficient in managing NSTEMI due to the risk of ongoing ischemia and potential progression to myocardial infarction. Immediate DAPT and anticoagulation are critical to stabilizing the patient and reducing further cardiac events.
  • • Option
  • • D. Observation with serial ECG monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NSTEMI is characterized by subtotal occlusion and platelet-rich thrombosis leading to myocardial ischemia. Immediate management includes dual antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation, followed by coronary angiography to determine the need for revascularization. Fibrinolysis is contraindicated in NSTEMI, highlighting the importance of distinguishing it from STEMI in acute management.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, Public health expert who works extensively with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India. In a meeting with local health workers in 2017, he has shared the data and progress made in controlling leprosy. He mentions the crucial statistic of the Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) as of March 31, 2016, to give a snapshot of the magnitude of new leprosy cases detected. This rate helps in understanding the effectiveness of ongoing programs and strategies. What value did Dr. Mehta share as the ANCDR for leprosy for that specific year? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 9.7/1 lakh population

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions. For leprosy in India, maintaining a keen understanding of this rate is essential for achieving the goals of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme.
  • ➤ The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions.
  • ➤ For leprosy in India, maintaining a keen understanding of this rate is essential for achieving the goals of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It is slower than AV nodal pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bundle of Kent is an accessory pathway connecting atrium and ventricle with conduction through Na+ channels leading to bypass of physiological AV conduction.

References:

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GIST

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance over the past three months. Physical examination reveals a palpable nodule on the right side of his neck and a mild tremor of his hands. Laboratory tests show elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH levels. A radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan is performed, report shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation and radioactive iodine uptake scan findings are consistent with a toxic adenoma, also known as a hyperfunctioning solitary thyroid nodule. Toxic adenomas are autonomous nodules that produce thyroid hormone independently of TSH regulation, leading to suppression of the rest of the thyroid gland. This condition typically presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations, and is confirmed by a RAIU scan showing increased uptake confined to the adenoma with suppression of uptake in the surrounding thyroid tissue.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Graves' disease: Graves' disease is characterized by diffuse increased uptake throughout the entire thyroid gland on a RAIU scan due to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins. It does not present as a solitary focus of increased uptake with suppression of the rest of the gland.
  • • Option
  • • A. Graves' disease:
  • • Option B. Toxic multinodular goiter: This condition involves multiple hyperfunctioning nodules within the thyroid gland, resulting in patchy areas of increased uptake on the RAIU scan. It differs from toxic adenoma, which shows a solitary area of increased uptake.
  • • Option
  • • B. Toxic multinodular goiter:
  • • Option D. Thyroiditis: Thyroiditis typically leads to decreased or absent iodine uptake on a RAIU scan due to inflammation and release of preformed thyroid hormone rather than increased production. It is not associated with a focal area of increased uptake.
  • • Option
  • • D. Thyroiditis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toxic adenoma is characterized by a solitary hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule that autonomously produces thyroid hormone, leading to suppression of TSH and suppression of the rest of the thyroid tissue on a RAIU scan. It presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism and is confirmed by localized increased uptake on imaging.

questions.text: A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination, he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2018) Opening pressure- increased Proteins- mildly increased Glucose – normal Lymphocytes- increased

Ans. D) Coxsackie

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CAD Prophylaxis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not recommended for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Although there was some belief in the past that HRT might provide cardiovascular benefits, extensive research has shown that HRT does not prevent CAD and may, in fact, increase the risk of certain cardiovascular events in some women.
  • • HRT is primarily indicated for the management of symptoms associated with menopause and for certain therapeutic and prophylactic uses:
  • • Therapeutic Indications:
  • • Therapeutic Indications:
  • • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents Premature ovarian failure Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms) Vaginal dryness
  • • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • • Premature ovarian failure
  • • Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms)
  • • Vaginal dryness
  • • Prophylactic Indications:
  • • Prophylactic Indications:
  • • Prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women
  • • Prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women
  • • Risks of HRT:
  • • Risks of HRT:
  • • Increased risk of endometrial cancer (particularly with unopposed estrogen in women with an intact uterus) Increased risk of breast cancer Increased risk of ovarian cancer Increased risk of thromboembolism Possible adverse effects on lipid profiles Increased risk of gallstones and liver dysfunction
  • • Increased risk of endometrial cancer (particularly with unopposed estrogen in women with an intact uterus)
  • • Increased risk of breast cancer
  • • Increased risk of ovarian cancer
  • • Increased risk of thromboembolism
  • • Possible adverse effects on lipid profiles
  • • Increased risk of gallstones and liver dysfunction
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Hot flashes: HRT is widely used to manage hot flashes and other vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause. It is one of the most effective treatments for these symptoms.
  • • Option A. Hot flashes:
  • • Option C. Osteoporosis: HRT is used prophylactically to prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women by maintaining bone density and reducing the risk of fractures.
  • • Option C. Osteoporosis:
  • • Option D. Premature menopause: Women experiencing premature menopause or premature ovarian failure can benefit from HRT to manage symptoms and reduce the long-term risks associated with early loss of estrogen, including osteoporosis.
  • • Option D. Premature menopause:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD).
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 61,62
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 61,62

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occludens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Integrin : Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option A. Integrin
  • • Option B. Cadherin : Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option B. Cadherin
  • • Option D. None of the above : Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option D. None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic sinusitis presents to the clinic with complaints of nasal congestion, anosmia (loss of smell), and recurrent episodes of facial pressure. She reports that these symptoms have been persistent for the past several months, despite using over-the-counter nasal sprays and decongestants. On physical examination, nasal endoscopy reveals bilateral pale, edematous masses in the nasal cavity consistent with nasal polyps. She denies any history of allergies or asthma as a child but notes that she developed wheezing and shortness of breath in her late 30s, which has been managed with inhalers. Nasal polyps are commonly associated with which conditions?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is commonly associated with nasal polyps. This form of asthma typically develops in adulthood and is not linked to an atopic or allergic component. The pathophysiology involves a non-IgE-mediated mechanism with chronic inflammation driven by eosinophils and neutrophils. Nasal polyps in intrinsic asthma arise from persistent inflammation of the nasal passages and sinuses, contributing to the common symptoms of nasal obstruction and anosmia. This condition contrasts with allergic asthma, which usually involves IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Allergic rhinitis: While allergic rhinitis is a common cause of nasal symptoms, it is more frequently associated with allergic asthma rather than intrinsic asthma. Nasal polyps can occur but are less characteristic in this context.
  • • Option
  • • A. Allergic rhinitis:
  • • Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Nasal polyps are seen in patients with cystic fibrosis due to chronic sinus infections and inflammation. However, cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder and not typically linked to adult-onset asthma.
  • • Option
  • • B. Cystic fibrosis:
  • • Option D. Wegener's granulomatosis: Also known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition can cause nasal symptoms, but it is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis, granuloma formation, and is not commonly associated with nasal polyps.
  • • Option
  • • D. Wegener's granulomatosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasal polyps are commonly associated with intrinsic (non-allergic) asthma, chronic sinusitis, and conditions involving persistent airway inflammation, such as cystic fibrosis. Unlike allergic asthma, intrinsic asthma does not involve IgE-mediated pathways and often develops in adulthood, with nasal polyps being a frequent comorbidity due to chronic inflammation of the nasal passages. Understanding the associations between nasal polyps and respiratory conditions helps guide diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1198-1199
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1198-1199

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022) ECHO. Ventilation-perfusion scan. Thermodilution. Fick's principle
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A, C, D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:
  • ➤ By using Fick principle Indicator (dye) dilution technique Thermodilution technique Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique Doppler echocardiography Ballisto cardiography.
  • ➤ By using Fick principle

  • ➤ Thermodilution technique

  • ➤ Doppler echocardiography
  • ➤ Ballisto cardiography.

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatigability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12 - 14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very less fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9gm/dl and MCV 120 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Folic acid deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of anemia in this patient, given the elevated MCV and dietary habits lacking in fruits and vegetables, is folic acid deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia due to folic acid deficiency presents with macrocytic red blood cells and can be confirmed by dietary history and characteristic blood smear findings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis. A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation. In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis. The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.
  • ➤ Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • ➤ A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • ➤ In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • ➤ The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) C4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of the CEAP Classification:
  • • The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:
  • • C : Clinical classification E : Etiologic classification A : Anatomic classification P : Pathophysiologic classification
  • • C : Clinical classification
  • • C
  • • E : Etiologic classification
  • • E
  • • A : Anatomic classification
  • • A
  • • P : Pathophysiologic classification
  • • P
  • • The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:
  • • C0 : No visible or palpable signs of venous disease. C1 : Telangiectasias or reticular veins. C2 : Varicose veins. C3 : Edema. C4 : Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into: C4a : Pigmentation or eczema. C4b : Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c : Corona phlebectatica C5 : Skin changes with healed ulceration. C6 : Skin changes with active ulceration.
  • • C0 : No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • • C0
  • • C1 : Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • • C1
  • • C2 : Varicose veins.
  • • C2
  • • C3 : Edema.
  • • C3
  • • C4 : Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into: C4a : Pigmentation or eczema. C4b : Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c : Corona phlebectatica
  • • C4
  • • C4a : Pigmentation or eczema. C4b : Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C4c : Corona phlebectatica
  • • C4a : Pigmentation or eczema.
  • • C4a
  • • C4b : Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • • C4b
  • • C4c : Corona phlebectatica
  • • C4c
  • • C5 : Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • • C5
  • • C6 : Skin changes with active ulceration.
  • • C6
  • • In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? ( INICET May 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum

options.label: D
options.text: Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.correct_answer: D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GIT HORMONES
  • ➤ GIT HORMONES
  • ➤ Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase. Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion. CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation. GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release. Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).
  • ➤ Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • ➤ Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion.
  • ➤ CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO 3 - secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • ➤ GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • ➤ Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm, which started 3 hours ago. He appears diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 95 beats per minute, and ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes. Given the timing of his symptoms, which biomarker would be the most appropriate investigation to diagnose myocardial infarction (MI) within 2-4 hours of symptom onset?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Myoglobin is one of the earliest cardiac biomarkers to rise after myocardial injury, typically elevating within 1 to 4 hours of symptom onset. It peaks around 12 hours and normalizes within 24 hours. Due to its rapid rise, myoglobin is particularly useful in detecting myocardial infarction in the early hours when other biomarkers may still be within normal ranges. However, its lack of specificity to cardiac tissue means that while it is highly sensitive for early detection, it must be used in conjunction with other tests to confirm a diagnosis of MI.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Troponin I (Tropl) Troponin I starts to rise within 3 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, making it less suitable for diagnosing MI within 2-4 hours of onset. Although Troponin I is highly specific for cardiac injury, its elevation time frame does not align with the immediate early phase of MI.
  • • Option
  • • B. Troponin I (Tropl)
  • • Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) LDH is a less specific marker of tissue injury and usually begins to rise 10 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, peaking at 48 to 72 hours. It is not used for early diagnosis of MI due to its delayed rise and lack of specificity for cardiac muscle damage.
  • • Option
  • • C. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
  • • Option D. Troponin T (TropT) Troponin T rises within 3 to 12 hours after myocardial infarction, peaking between 12 and 48 hours, and remains elevated for 7 to 10 days. It is highly specific for myocardial injury but is not an ideal early marker within the 2-4 hour window of symptom onset.
  • • Option
  • • D. Troponin T (TropT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myoglobin is the earliest cardiac biomarker to rise following myocardial injury, usually within 1 to 4 hours, making it particularly useful for diagnosing myocardial infarction in the acute phase. Troponins, while highly specific and sensitive for cardiac injury, typically begin to rise later, around 3 to 12 hours after symptom onset. Understanding the time courses of various biomarkers is crucial in selecting the appropriate tests for early diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
